docs.lead_paragraph: Can free manicures and the lure of cold cash keep teen-age girls from getting pregnant? Gil Burnett, a retired trial judge from New Hanover County, N.C., thinks it's worth a try. Frustrated by 23 years of punishing crimes whose ''root cause,'' he says, was unwanted pregnancy, Burnett is pushing a plan called Project for Happier Lives, which would entice young women to stay un-pregnant through cash sweepstakes. Under it, any girl age 10 to 19 could enroll in three years of monthly classes in money management, career planning and (the crux) saying no to sexual advances, a subject Burnett has dubbed ''Games Guys Play 101.'' For staying un-pregnant, each girl would get the chance to win monthly drawings of $25 gifts (for hairdos and the like) and a $5,000 grand prize at the end of the year. Though the community has agreed that the program makes sense, there has been pointed opposition to the idea that society can buy good behavior. Burnett, who characterizes himself as a die-hard realist, argues that the plan is an unusual but reasonable technique for a county that had 200 teen-age pregnancies in 1996. At the moment, the county commission has stalled on whether to allow the health department to offer official support, but Burnett is steaming ahead with more than $15,000 in private financing and a vision of the project being replicated nationwide. Meanwhile, Burnett's supporters are not moved by the argument that purchased virtue is a vice.
docs.abstract: Gil Burnett, retired North Carolina judge, is pushing plan to encourage young women not to get pregnant by offering prizes in monthly cash sweepstakes; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-13 Traffickers in Sex Victimizing Slavic Women Across the world, the selling of naive and desperate young women into sexual bondage has become one of the fastest-growing criminal enterprises. Since the fall of Communism, experts say, women from Russia and Ukraine are being particularly victimized. ''Can people really buy and sell women and get away with it?'' asked one dismayed young woman. 1 Pressure on Suharto Grows Indonesia's leading opposition figure, Megawati Sukarnoputri, called on President Suharto to step down when his term ends in March and said she was ready to succeed him. As the nation's economic problems reached crisis proportions, pressure grew from other quarters, too, for Mr. Suharto to end his 32-year rule. 8

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that its U.S. Healthcare health plans would eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, on April 1. The company said that women who had fertility problems had been joining the U.S. Healthcare plans because they knew the advanced treatments were available. Aetna has recently been under pressure from Wall Street investors to reduce costs and increase profits.
docs.abstract: US Healthcare unit of Aetna Inc will eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization; says women were joining its plans because they knew the advanced treatments were available; Aetna has been under pressure from Wall Street investors to reduce costs and increase profits; decision is criticized by doctors and advocates of infertility patients, who say many couples are already struggling to cover costs of such treatments out of their own pockets; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The growing problem of the uninsured is likely to receive yet more political attention next week: aides say Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to announce a program in his State of the City address that could make it easier for small businesses to offer insurance to employees. Earlier this week, Gov. George E. Pataki, like Mr. Giuliani a Republican, used his State of the State address to discuss his goal of providing health coverage to all uninsured children in the state who are younger than 19.

headline.main: Mayor Plans System to Help Small Firms Insure Workers

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani reportedly will announce program in State of the City address that could make it easier for small businesses to offer health insurance to employees; modest plan would provide money to private organization to help city's 212,000 small businesses find health insurance policies for employees and families (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Daniel Ezra Johnson calculates that leaf-blowing gardeners can earn $4,200 a month in Los Angeles (letter, Jan. 9). That he regards these gardeners as ''well off'' indicates little knowledge of small businesses.
docs.abstract: Thomas F Murphy letter replies to Jan 9 letter that suggested that a lawn-care business that grosses $4,200 month qualifies its owner as well-off (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks Tumble in U.S. As Asian Worries Mount Stocks tumbled, driven down in huge waves of selling on fears over how deeply America's economy will be hurt by Asia's festering financial crisis. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 222.2 points, or 2.85 percent, its sharpest drop since October's plunge. For the week, the Dow was down 4.8 percent. Broader market measures were also sharply lower.

docs.lead_paragraph: I want to be a dynamic corporation boss. Then the newspapers would run my picture wearing this incredibly expensive suit. It would be a hand-stitched suit. I would know what hand-stitched means. The financial writers would all call me a C.E.O. I already know what that means: Chief Executive Officer. I would merge, acquire, downsize, outsource, cut costs.
docs.abstract: Russell Baker column on his fantasies about being a CEO, a top professional athlete, a titan of Wall Street, a rock star or an heir to a great fortune and getting away with all the outrageous behavior they display (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The ambitious health care plan for children that Gov. George E. Pataki announced with such fanfare in his State of the State address on Wednesday is less a set of blueprints than a concept -- and one already under dispute in Albany. The Governor said in his speech that he wanted to provide health care to every child in New York 18 years old and under, in what would be a major expansion of a state program that has existed since 1991. The idea would not cost the state a cent because the Federal Government has already earmarked more than $250 million a year for children's health care in New York.

headline.main: Health Plan Is Ambitious, But Critics See Problems

docs.abstract: Analysis of health care plan for children announced by Gov George E Pataki in his State of the State address; says it is less a plan than a concept, and one that does not go far enough, according to critics; they say program should cover many more children whose families would not qualify for insurance now, and that benefits should be broadened to include services like dental care, vision and hearing; they want health program to look more like Medicaid; such a move might earn Pataki praise in New York City in his re-election run, but it would be difficult for him to explain to conservative voters; Pataki came into office four years ago promising to cut pricey Government entitlements like Medicaid (M)
docs.snippet: The ambitious health care plan for children that Gov. George E. Pataki announced with such fanfare in his State of the State address on Wednesday is less a set of blueprints than a concept -- and one already under dispute in Albany.    The Governor...

docs.lead_paragraph: The gilded Palais des Nations in Geneva is a perfect setting for the elite group of industry executives and government regulators who regularly meet there to establish worldwide auto safety regulations for the next century. A sign marked ''Private'' prevented anyone not part of the official 90-member delegation from entering the last gathering held in November. As they decide public safety issues from emission standards to safety belts that will affect drivers and passengers around the world, the Geneva negotiators do not have to adhere to many of the rules requiring openness to the public and interest groups that govern similar proceedings in the United States.

headline.main: Where Business Rules; Forging Global Regulations That Put Industry First

docs.abstract: Decades-long effort to expand global trade has shifted from focus on tariffs to efforts to reduce other types of trade barriers since World Trade Organization was created three years ago; international standards-setting forums--many of which originated before WTO--have taken on growing importance; many of these groups, mostly consisting of business and government interests, do not have to respond to public comments and have restrictive eligibility requirements for outsiders; many American regulatory operations were created to address social concerns and before global trade was so important; now some of these rules are seen as impediments that can block markets and cause inefficiency; some of issues global rule makers are dealing with discussed; photo (L)
docs.snippet: The gilded Palais des Nations in Geneva is a perfect setting for the elite group of industry executives and government regulators who regularly meet there to establish worldwide auto safety regulations for the next century. A sign marked ''Private''...

docs.lead_paragraph: The biggest question raised by Gov. George Pataki's State of the State speech yesterday was what he saved to say when he announces for re-election. This speech was supposed to be about the challenges New York State has yet to meet, but its agenda was both modest and overly focused on campaign headlines. The Governor failed to make a single mention of campaign finance reform. He did not speak of rebuilding the crumbling and overcrowded schools in many parts of New York. There was no offer of support for the drive by New York City's Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, to end tenure for public school principals. The Governor talked about creating jobs, but overlooked infrastructure -- the subway and rail service improvements needed to get workers to those jobs in New York City.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Gov George E Pataki's State of State speech was supposed to be about challenges New York State has yet to meet, but its agenda was both modest and overly focused on campaign headlines; maintains that one important exception to trivial tone was call for making health care coverage available to every uninsured child in state; notes that New York City Council Speaker, Peter Vallone, criticized Pataki's tax cuts in his State of City speech as being fiscally dangerous, but then proposed $500 million reduction in city's personal income tax and expensive new after-school programs without any balancing spending cuts (M)
